_link.title: I can describe the role of the weak nuclear force in beta decay

toLevel2.question: What is the primary role of the weak nuclear force in the nucleus?
options: Transforming neutrons into protons and vice versa
toLevel2.correct: Transforming neutrons into protons and vice versa
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The weak nuclear force is responsible for changing one type of nucleon into another, enabling beta decay.

distractorExplanations.Holding the nucleus together: This is the role of the strong nuclear force, not the weak force.
distractorExplanations.Repelling protons: Electrostatic force repels protons; the weak force transforms particles.
distractorExplanations.Attracting electrons: Electromagnetic force attracts electrons; the weak force acts within nucleons.

toLevel2.question: Which type of radioactive decay is caused by the weak nuclear force?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Beta decay involves the transformation of neutrons to protons (or vice versa), which is mediated by the weak force.

distractorExplanations.Alpha decay: Alpha decay involves strong force effects, emitting helium nuclei.
distractorExplanations.Gamma decay: Gamma decay involves electromagnetic transitions, not the weak force.
distractorExplanations.Nuclear fission: Fission involves the strong force and electrostatic repulsion.

toLevel2.question: What happens to a neutron during beta-minus decay?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: In beta-minus decay, the weak force transforms a neutron into a proton while emitting an electron (beta particle) and an antineutrino.

distractorExplanations.It transforms into an electron: The neutron becomes a proton; the electron is emitted, not created from the neutron directly.
distractorExplanations.It disappears completely: The neutron transforms; it doesn't simply vanish.
distractorExplanations.It stays unchanged: Beta decay specifically involves neutron-proton transformation.

toLevel2.question: Over what range does the weak nuclear force act?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The weak force acts over an extremely short range, about 10⁻¹⁸ m, even shorter than the strong nuclear force.

distractorExplanations.About 10⁻¹⁵ m: This is the range of the strong nuclear force, not the weak force.
distractorExplanations.Infinite range: The weak force has a very limited range, unlike electromagnetic force.
distractorExplanations.About 10⁻¹⁰ m: This is atomic scale, much larger than the weak force range.

toLevel2.question: What element does carbon-14 transform into during beta decay?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: When C-14 undergoes beta-minus decay, a neutron becomes a proton, increasing the atomic number from 6 to 7, producing nitrogen.

distractorExplanations.Boron-14: Beta-minus decay increases atomic number; boron has Z=5, which is lower than carbon.
distractorExplanations.Carbon-12: Carbon-12 would be an isotope of carbon, but beta decay changes the element.
distractorExplanations.Oxygen-14: Oxygen (Z=8) would require two protons to be added, not one.

toLevel2.question: The weak nuclear force is responsible for {{c1::beta}} decay in radioactive nuclei.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Beta decay occurs when the weak force transforms a neutron into a proton or vice versa.

toLevel2.question: During beta-minus decay, a {{c1::neutron}} is transformed into a proton.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The weak force changes a neutron into a proton, emitting an electron and antineutrino in the process.

toLevel2.question: The weak nuclear force has an extremely short range of about {{c1::10⁻¹⁸}} metres.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: This is about 1000 times shorter than the strong force range, making the weak force act only within nucleons.

toLevel2.question: The weak nuclear force is responsible for holding the nucleus together.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The strong nuclear force holds the nucleus together. The weak force transforms particle types during beta decay.

toLevel2.question: Beta decay allows nuclei to change their neutron-to-proton ratio.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: By converting neutrons to protons or vice versa, beta decay adjusts the n:p ratio toward stability.

toLevel3.question: Why is the weak force important for nuclear stability?
options: It allows nuclei to adjust their neutron-to-proton ratio toward stability
It holds protons and neutrons together
It repels neutrons from the nucleus
toLevel3.correct: It allows nuclei to adjust their neutron-to-proton ratio toward stability
toLevel3.correctExplanation: By enabling neutron-proton transformation, the weak force provides a mechanism for unstable nuclei to reach more stable configurations.

distractorExplanations.It holds protons and neutrons together: This is the role of the strong force.
distractorExplanations.It prevents all radioactive decay: The weak force enables certain types of decay, not prevents them.
distractorExplanations.It repels neutrons from the nucleus: The weak force transforms particles; it doesn't repel them.

toLevel3.question: Why does a neutron-rich nucleus undergo beta-minus decay?
options: Converting a neutron to a proton decreases the neutron-to-proton ratio
The strong force pushes neutrons out
Electrons are attracted into the nucleus
toLevel3.correct: Converting a neutron to a proton decreases the neutron-to-proton ratio
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Beta-minus decay converts n→p, reducing the n:p ratio toward the stable region.

distractorExplanations.It has too many protons: Neutron-rich nuclei have too few protons, not too many.
distractorExplanations.The strong force pushes neutrons out: The strong force doesn't selectively push neutrons out.
distractorExplanations.Electrons are attracted into the nucleus: Electrons are emitted, not absorbed, in beta-minus decay.

toLevel3.question: Why does the weak force have such a short range?
options: It is mediated by massive W and Z bosons
It only acts on small particles
toLevel3.correct: It is mediated by massive W and Z bosons
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The large mass of W and Z bosons (about 80-90 GeV/c²) limits the range to ~10⁻¹⁸ m according to the uncertainty principle.

distractorExplanations.It is the weakest force: Being weak doesn't determine range; gravity is weaker but has infinite range.
distractorExplanations.It only acts on small particles: Range depends on mediator mass, not particle size.
distractorExplanations.It is blocked by neutrons: The weak force acts on neutrons; they don't block it.

toLevel3.question: During beta-plus decay, what transformation occurs?
options: A proton transforms into a neutron
A neutron transforms into a proton
toLevel3.correct: A proton transforms into a neutron
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Beta-plus decay converts a proton into a neutron, emitting a positron and neutrino, increasing the n:p ratio.

distractorExplanations.A neutron transforms into a proton: This is beta-minus decay, not beta-plus.
distractorExplanations.Two neutrons combine: Beta decay involves nucleon transformation, not combination.
distractorExplanations.An electron enters the nucleus: That would be electron capture, a related but different process.

toLevel3.question: Why is the weak force called 'weak'?
options: Its effects occur slowly compared to strong and electromagnetic forces
It only works on small nuclei
It is blocked by all matter
toLevel3.correct: Its effects occur slowly compared to strong and electromagnetic forces
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The weak force produces effects more slowly (longer half-lives) than strong or electromagnetic processes, hence 'weak'.

distractorExplanations.It can't affect any particles: The weak force does affect particles; it causes beta decay.
distractorExplanations.It only works on small nuclei: The weak force acts in all nuclei where conditions allow.
distractorExplanations.It is blocked by all matter: The weak force operates within nucleons; it's not blocked externally.

toLevel3.question: A proton-rich nucleus may undergo {{c1::beta-plus}} decay to increase its neutron count.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Beta-plus decay converts a proton to a neutron, increasing the neutron-to-proton ratio toward stability.

toLevel3.question: The weak force allows nuclei to reach more {{c1::stable}} configurations by adjusting their composition.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: By enabling nucleon transformation, the weak force provides a pathway to the belt of stability.

toLevel3.question: The weak nuclear force is mediated by massive particles called {{c1::W and Z bosons}}.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: These heavy gauge bosons (W⁺, W⁻, Z⁰) carry the weak force and give it its short range.

toLevel3.question: Beta-plus decay and beta-minus decay both involve the weak nuclear force.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Both types of beta decay involve nucleon transformation mediated by the weak force.

toLevel3.question: The weak force has a longer range than the strong nuclear force.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The weak force range (~10⁻¹⁸ m) is much shorter than the strong force range (~10⁻¹⁵ m).

toLevel4.question: Carbon-14 (6 protons, 8 neutrons) undergoes beta-minus decay. What are the proton and neutron numbers of the daughter nucleus?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Beta-minus: n→p. Starting with 6p, 8n → 7p, 7n. The daughter is N-14 with equal protons and neutrons.

distractorExplanations.5 protons, 9 neutrons: This would be boron, formed by beta-plus decay, not beta-minus.
distractorExplanations.6 protons, 7 neutrons: This would lose a neutron without converting it, which isn't beta decay.
distractorExplanations.7 protons, 8 neutrons: The total nucleon count must stay at 14, so 7p requires 7n.

toLevel4.question: A free neutron has a half-life of about 10 minutes, while neutrons in stable nuclei don't decay. Why?
options: In stable nuclei, converting a neutron to a proton would increase energy
The weak force doesn't work inside nuclei
Neutrons become stable when surrounded by protons
toLevel4.correct: In stable nuclei, converting a neutron to a proton would increase energy
toLevel4.correctExplanation: In stable nuclei, the nuclear binding makes neutron→proton conversion energetically unfavourable, preventing decay.

distractorExplanations.The weak force doesn't work inside nucle: The weak force does act in nuclei; it causes beta decay in unstable nuclei.
distractorExplanations.Protons protect neutrons from decay: It's energy considerations, not physical protection.
distractorExplanations.Neutrons become stable when surrounded b: Stability depends on energy balance, not simply proximity to protons.

toLevel4.question: During beta-minus decay, conservation laws require additional particles to be emitted. What is emitted along with the electron?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Conservation of lepton number requires an antineutrino to be emitted with the electron in beta-minus decay.

distractorExplanations.A proton: The proton remains in the nucleus; it's not emitted.
distractorExplanations.A photon: Photons are emitted in gamma decay, not specifically required in beta decay.
distractorExplanations.A positron: Positrons are emitted in beta-plus decay, not beta-minus.

toLevel4.question: Phosphorus-32 (15 protons, 17 neutrons) is a beta-minus emitter. What element does it decay into?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Beta-minus increases atomic number by 1: P (Z=15) → S (Z=16).

distractorExplanations.Silicon (Si): Silicon has Z=14, which would result from beta-plus decay, not beta-minus.
distractorExplanations.Chlorine (Cl): Chlorine has Z=17, requiring two proton increases.
distractorExplanations.Phosphorus (P): Beta decay changes the element; it doesn't stay as phosphorus.

toLevel4.question: Electron capture is an alternative to beta-plus decay. What happens in electron capture?
options: An inner electron is captured by a proton, converting it to a neutron
An electron is emitted from the nucleus
A neutron captures an external electron
toLevel4.correct: An inner electron is captured by a proton, converting it to a neutron
toLevel4.correctExplanation: In electron capture, a proton absorbs an inner orbital electron, converting to a neutron via the weak force.

distractorExplanations.An electron is emitted from the nucleus: This describes beta-minus decay, not electron capture.
distractorExplanations.A neutron captures an external electron: Neutrons don't capture electrons; protons do in this process.
distractorExplanations.The nucleus captures a positron: Positrons are antimatter and annihilate with electrons; they're not captured.

toLevel4.question: When P-32 (15p, 17n) undergoes beta-minus decay, it becomes {{c1::S-32}} (16p, 16n).
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Beta-minus converts n→p: 15p→16p, 17n→16n. Element 16 is sulfur, mass number stays 32.

toLevel4.question: In beta-minus decay, an electron and an {{c1::antineutrino}} are emitted.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Conservation of lepton number requires an electron antineutrino to accompany the electron.

toLevel4.question: Electron capture produces the same nuclear change as {{c1::beta-plus}} decay but without emitting a positron.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Both processes convert a proton to a neutron, but electron capture absorbs an electron rather than emitting a positron.

toLevel4.question: In beta decay, the mass number of the nucleus changes.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Beta decay converts one nucleon type to another (n↔p), so total nucleon count (mass number) remains constant.

toLevel4.question: Tritium (H-3) undergoes beta-minus decay to become helium-3.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: H-3 (1p, 2n) → He-3 (2p, 1n) via beta-minus decay, where a neutron becomes a proton.

toLevel5.question: The weak force violates parity (mirror symmetry). What evidence first demonstrated this?
options: Beta electrons are emitted preferentially in one direction relative to nuclear spin
Beta decay happens at the same rate in all directions
The weak force is stronger on the right side of nuclei
toLevel5.correct: Beta electrons are emitted preferentially in one direction relative to nuclear spin
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Wu's experiment showed that in aligned cobalt-60 nuclei, beta particles were emitted asymmetrically, proving parity violation.

distractorExplanations.Beta decay happens at the same rate in a: This would indicate parity conservation, not violation.
distractorExplanations.Neutrons and protons decay identically: This isn't related to parity symmetry.
distractorExplanations.The weak force is stronger on the right: Parity violation is about mirror symmetry, not left-right strength differences.

toLevel5.question: The electroweak theory unifies the weak force with which other force?
toLevel5.correctExplanation: At high energies, the electromagnetic and weak forces are unified into the electroweak force, for which Glashow, Weinberg, and Salam won the Nobel Prize.

distractorExplanations.Strong nuclear force: Strong force unification (GUT) is still theoretical and unconfirmed.
distractorExplanations.Gravitational force: Gravity has not been unified with other forces yet.
distractorExplanations.No other force: The electroweak unification is a confirmed part of the Standard Model.

toLevel5.question: Why do neutrinos interact so weakly with matter?
options: They only interact via the weak force, which has extremely short range
They travel too fast to interact
toLevel5.correct: They only interact via the weak force, which has extremely short range
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Neutrinos have no charge and no colour charge, so they only experience the weak force, leading to very rare interactions.

distractorExplanations.They travel too fast to interact: Speed doesn't prevent interactions; cross-section determines interaction probability.
distractorExplanations.They have no mass: Neutrinos do have small masses, and mass isn't why they interact weakly.
distractorExplanations.They are absorbed by protons: Neutrino-proton interactions are rare, not common.

toLevel5.question: Double beta decay, where two neutrons simultaneously convert to protons, can occur in some nuclei. Why is this scientifically interesting?
options: Neutrinoless double beta decay would prove neutrinos are their own antiparticle
It happens faster than single beta decay
It proves the weak force doesn't exist
toLevel5.correct: Neutrinoless double beta decay would prove neutrinos are their own antiparticle
toLevel5.correctExplanation: If neutrinos are Majorana particles (their own antiparticle), neutrinoless double beta decay could occur, which is actively being searched for.

distractorExplanations.It happens faster than single beta decay: Double beta decay is extremely rare and slow, not fast.
distractorExplanations.It proves the weak force doesn't exist: Double beta decay is mediated by the weak force.
distractorExplanations.It violates conservation of energy: Conservation laws are maintained in double beta decay.

toLevel5.question: The continuous energy spectrum of beta particles was historically puzzling. How did the neutrino hypothesis resolve this?
options: The neutrino carries variable energy, ensuring total energy is conserved
Beta particles always have the same energy
Energy isn't conserved in beta decay
toLevel5.correct: The neutrino carries variable energy, ensuring total energy is conserved
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The energy released is shared between the electron and neutrino in varying proportions, explaining the continuous spectrum while conserving total energy.

distractorExplanations.Beta particles always have the same ener: This contradicts observations; beta energies vary continuously.
distractorExplanations.Energy isn't conserved in beta decay: Energy is conserved; this was why the neutrino was proposed.
distractorExplanations.The nucleus absorbs extra energy: The nucleus receives recoil energy, but this doesn't explain the continuous spectrum.

toLevel5.question: The 1956 Wu experiment demonstrated that the weak force violates {{c1::parity}} symmetry.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Parity (mirror symmetry) was shown to be violated when beta electrons from aligned Co-60 nuclei were emitted asymmetrically.

toLevel5.question: At high energies, the weak and electromagnetic forces unify into the {{c1::electroweak}} force.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The electroweak unification shows that at energies above ~100 GeV, these forces behave as one.

toLevel5.question: The continuous energy spectrum of beta particles led Pauli to propose the existence of the {{c1::neutrino}}.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: To conserve energy and momentum, Pauli hypothesised an invisible particle carrying away the 'missing' energy.

toLevel5.question: The weak force is the only force that can change quark flavour (e.g., down quark to up quark).
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Flavour-changing processes require the weak force; strong and electromagnetic forces conserve quark flavour.

toLevel5.question: The discovery of W and Z bosons confirmed the electroweak theory predictions.
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The W and Z bosons were discovered at CERN in 1983 with masses matching electroweak predictions, confirming the theory.
